description: From Middle English trameyle, from Old French tramail (“net for catching fish”), from Late Latin tremaculum. See Italian tramaglio.

entries.meaning: Whatever impedes activity, progress, or freedom, such as a net or shackle.
examples: [They] disclaim the trammels of any sordid contract.

entries.meaning: A fishing net that has large mesh at the edges and smaller mesh in the middle
A kind of net for catching birds, fishes, or other prey.
examples: The tuck carrieth a like fashion , save that it is narrower meshed , and ( therefore scarce lawful ) with a long bunt in the midst : the trammel differeth not much from the shape of this bunt, and serveth to such use as the wear and haking.

entries.meaning: A set of rings or other hanging devices, attached to a transverse bar suspended over a fire, used to hang cooking pots etc.
A net for confining a woman's hair.
A kind of shackle used for regulating the motions of a horse and making it amble.

(engineering) An instrument for drawing ellipses, one part of which consists of a cross with two grooves at right angles to each other, the other being a beam carrying two pins (which slide in those grooves), and also the describing pencil.

verbs.description: trammel (third-person singular simple present trammels, present participle (UK) trammelling or (US) trammeling, simple past and past participle (UK) trammelled or (US) trammeled)

entries.meaning: To entangle, as in a net.
examples: Which deepening pain left to his lordliest powers: —

entries.meaning: (transitive) To confine; to hamper; to shackle.
